big_picture_notes: Habakkuk is a compact prophetic dialogue/theodicy framed by a title (1:1) and a liturgical colophon (3:19). Its movement is chiastic (A–B–C–B'–A'): Complaint 1 (1:2–4) ↔ Answer 1 (1:5–11); Complaint 2 (1:12–2:1) ↔ Answer 2 with Five Woes (2:2–20); Resolution in a prayer‑psalm (3:1–19). The hinge is 2:4 ('the righteous shall live by his faith'), contrasting the proud with the faithful. Literary glue includes courtroom‑style questions, repeated lexemes (ḥāmas/violence; see/vision; judgment), formal 'woe' oracles, and the Divine Warrior theophany in ch. 3 that transforms fear into rejoicing.

stories.story_title: The Prophet's Two Complaints and God's First Answer
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Introduces the problem of divine justice via two laments (internal Judahite injustice; then Babylon’s ravages) and God’s first reply. Start (1:1): oracle title. End (2:1): prophet posts himself to await the response. Glue: dialogic alternation, repeated terms (violence, see, judgment) and the progression from 'How long?' to watchful waiting.

scenes.scene_name: Title and the First Wail of Injustice
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Superscription opens; four‑part lament culminates with law paralyzed and justice perverted. Devices: 'How long?' complaint, rhetorical questions, synonymous parallelism.

Divine speech commands 'Look among the nations' and depicts swift, ruthless Chaldeans; closes as they are guilty—power is their god. Devices: irony, hyperbole, rapid predator imagery (eagle, wolf, wind).

scenes.scene_name: The Second Complaint: Why Use the Wicked?
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Prophet affirms Yahweh’s holiness and questions using the wicked; fisher/net metaphor indicts Babylon’s idolatrous might; ends as he takes his stand to await an answer. Devices: contrast, metaphor (net/hook), narrative pivot to watchfulness.

stories.story_title: God's Vision and the Five Woes
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Authoritative answer commands inscription of the vision and establishes the faith principle (2:4–5), followed by a taunt‑song of five woes (2:6, 9, 12, 15, 19) against the oppressor, concluding with universal silence before Yahweh. Start (2:2): 'Write the vision.' End (2:20): temple silence. Glue: woe refrains, lex talionis, and doxological asides (2:14).

scenes.scene_name: The Vision and the Principle of Faith
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Instruction to write/await the vision; thesis contrasts proud soul with 'the righteous shall live by his faith'; ends with greed/drunkenness transition. Devices: antithetical parallelism, programmatic thesis.
Taunt begins; retribution for heaping up what is not one’s own and shedding blood—remnant will plunder the plunderer. Devices: taunt‑song, lex talionis.

scenes.scene_name: Woe 2: Against Unjust Gain and Treachery
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Evil gain for one’s house to set nest on high; stones and beams cry out. Devices: unjust security motif, personification of materials as witnesses.
Town built with blood condemned; labor is for fire; interjected promise: earth filled with Yahweh’s glory. Devices: proverbial oracle, eschatological doxology.
Forcing neighbors to drink and gaze at nakedness; cup in Yahweh’s hand returns shame; violence to Lebanon/beasts revisits the oppressor. Devices: irony, cup‑of‑wrath motif, retributive justice.
Idols profit nothing; mute teachers mocked; closes with 'Yahweh in his holy temple—let all the earth keep silence.' Devices: rhetorical questions, temple theophany and silence.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: A self‑contained prayer‑psalm resolves the dialogue: title (3:1), petition for revival/mercy (3:2), Divine Warrior theophany (3:3–15), personal trembling yet trust (3:16–19), with musical colophon. Start (3:1): prayer superscription. End (3:19): 'To the choirmaster…' Glue: fear‑to‑faith arc, reuse of theophanic motifs now as hope.

scenes.scene_name: Prayer Title and Request for Revival
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Superscription 'according to Shigionoth'; plea to revive the work and remember mercy 'in the midst of years.' Devices: psalmic petition, temporal refrain.
God comes from Teman/Paran; brightness, pestilence, trembling nations; ends with Cushan/Midian in dread. Devices: theophany imagery, merism, parallelism.
Rhetorical questions to rivers/sea; arrows, spears, sun/moon; salvation for your people; trample the sea with horses. Devices: mythopoetic combat, cosmic subjugation.

scenes.scene_name: The Prophet's Confession of Awe and Fear
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Single‑verse pivot: bodily trembling turns to quiet waiting for the day of distress. Devices: first‑person confession, emotional hinge.

'Though… yet' faith stanza moves from agricultural loss to rejoicing in God; 'makes my feet like the deer' and musical colophon conclude. Devices: antithetical hymn of trust, high‑places metaphor, liturgical ending.
